title: Vertical collision blocks on a spring

content.question:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Block <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of mass <math alttext="M"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at rest and attached to the top of a spring. The block compresses the spring a distance <math alttext="d"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from its uncompressed length at equilibrium. Block <math alttext="B"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of mass <math alttext="2 M"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is released from rest at a height <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above block <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The two blocks collide and stick together. Express all answers in terms of <math alttext="d"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="h"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(a) Derive an expression for the spring constant <math alttext="k"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the spring.

(b) Derive an expression for the speed of block <math alttext="B"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> just before it collides with block <math alttext="A"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(c) Derive an expression for the speed of the blocks immediately after the collision.
(d) Derive an expression for the maximum compression of the spring after the collision.
(e) If the collision between the blocks was elastic, would the maximum compression of the spring be greater than, less than, or equal to that found in part (d)? Justify your answer.
